According to legend, each translator worked in solitary confinement in his own cell, and, according to legend, all seventy versions proved identical. The ''Septuagint'' became the [[source text]] for later translations into many languages, including [[Latin]], [[Coptic language|Coptic]], [[Armenian language|Armenian]] and [[Georgian language|Georgian]].
Still considered one of the greatest translators in history, for having rendered the ''[[Bible]]'' into [[Latin]], is [[Jerome]] (347–420 C.E.), the [[patron saint]] of translators. For centuries the [[Roman Catholic Church]] used his translation (known as the [[Vulgate]]), though even this translation stirred controversy. By contrast with Jerome's contemporary, [[Augustine of Hippo]] (354–430 C.E.), who endorsed precise translation, Jerome believed in adaptation, and sometimes invention, in order to more effectively bring across the meaning. Jerome's colorful Vulgate translation of the Bible includes some crucial instances of "overdetermination". For example, [[Isaiah]]'s prophecy announcing that the Savior will be born of a virgin, uses the word '''almah'', which is also used to describe the dancing girls at [[Solomon]]'s court, and simply means young and nubile. Jerome, writes [[Marina Warner]], translates it as ''virgo'', "adding divine authority to the virulent cult of [[sex]]ual disgust that shaped Christian moral theology (the [Moslem] ''[[Quran]]'', free from this linguistic trap, does not connect [[Maryam (name)|Mariam]]/[[Mary, mother of Jesus|Mary]]'s miraculous nature with moral horror of sex)." The [[apple]] that [[Eve]] offered to [[Adam]], according to Mark Polizzotti, could equally well have been an [[apricot]], [[orange (fruit)|orange]], or [[banana]]; but Jerome liked the [[pun]] ''malus/malum'' (apple/evil}.<ref>[[Marina Warner]], "The Politics of Translation" (a review of [[Kate Briggs]], ''This Little Art'', 2017; [[Mireille Gansel]], translated by [[Ros Schwartz]], 2017; [[Mark Polizzotti]], ''Sympathy for the Traitor: A Translation Manifesto'', 2018; [[Boyd Tonkin]], ed., ''The 100 Best Novels in Translation'', 2018; [[Clive Scott (linguist)|Clive Scott]], ''The Work of Literary Translation'', 2018), ''[[London Review of Books]]'', vol. 40, no. 19 (11 October 2018), p. 22.</ref>
[[Pope Francis]] has suggested that the phrase "lead us not into temptation", in the [[Lord's Prayer]] found in the [[Gospel of Matthew|Gospels of Matthew]] (the first Gospel, written c. 80–90 C.E.) and [[Gospel of Luke|Luke]] (the third Gospel, written c. 80–110 C.E.), should more properly be translated, "do not let us fall into temptation", commenting that God does not lead people into temptation—[[Satan]] does.{{efn|MJC Warren, Lecturer in Biblical and Religious Studies, [[University of Sheffield]], points out (more explicitly than Charles McNamara) that Luke gives a shorter version of [[Jesus]]'s Lord's Prayer, leaving off the request that God "deliver us from evil"; that (as Charles McNamara also says) accurate translation is not the question here; and that the Bible records a number of incidents when God commands evil actions, such as that [[Abraham]] kill his only son, [[Isaac]] (whose execution is canceled at the last moment).<ref>MJC Warren, "‘Lead us not into temptation’: why Pope Francis is wrong about the Lord’s Prayer", ''[[The Conversation]]'', December 8, 2017 [https://theconversation.com/lead-us-not-into-temptation-why-pope-francis-is-wrong-about-the-lords-prayer-88886]</ref>}} Some important early Christian authors interpreted the Bible's Greek text and [[Jerome]]'s [[Latin Vulgate]] similarly to Pope Francis. A.J.B. Higgins<ref>A.J.B. Higgins, "'Lead Us Not into Temptation': Some Latin Variants", ''[[Journal of Theological Studies]]'', 1943.</ref> in 1943 showed that among the earliest Christian authors, the understanding and even the text of this devotional verse underwent considerable changes. These ancient writers suggest that, even if the Greek and Latin texts are left unmodified, something like "do not let us fall" could be an acceptable English rendering. Higgins cited [[Tertullian]], the earliest of the Latin [[Church Fathers]] (c. 155–c. 240 C.E., "do not allow us to be led") and [[Cyprian]] (c. 200–258 C.E., "do not allow us to be led into temptation"). A later author, [[Ambrose]] (C. 340–397 C.E.), followed Cyprian's interpretation. [[Augustine of Hippo]] (354–430), familiar with Jerome's Latin Vulgate rendering, observed that "many people... say it this way: 'and do not allow us to be led into temptation.'"<ref>Charles McNamara, "Lead Us Not into Temptation? Francis Is Not the First to Question a Key Phrase of the Lord's Prayer", ''[[Commonweal (magazine)|Commonweal]]'', January 1, 2018. [https://www.commonwealmagazine.org/lead-us-not-temptation]</ref>
In 863 C.E. the brothers [[Saints Cyril and Methodius]], the [[Byzantine Empire]]'s "Apostles to the Slavs", began translating parts of the [[Bible]] into the [[Old Church Slavonic]] language, using the [[Glagolitic script]] that they had devised, based on the [[Greek alphabet]].
The periods preceding and contemporary with the [[Protestant Reformation]] saw translations of the [[Bible]] into [[vernacular]] (local) European languages—a development that contributed to [[Western Christianity]]'s split into [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]] and [[Protestantism]] over disparities between Catholic and Protestant renderings of crucial words and passages (and due to a Protestant-perceived need to reform the Roman Catholic Church). Lasting effects on the religions, cultures, and languages of their respective countries were exerted by such [[Bible]] translations as [[Martin Luther]]'s into [[German language|German]] (the [[New Testament]], 1522), [[Jakub Wujek]]'s into [[Polish language|Polish]] (1599, as revised by the [[Jesuits]]), and [[William Tyndale]]'s (New Testament, 1526 and revisions) and the ''[[King James Version]]'' into [[English language|English]] (1611). [[File:Moses (Michaelangelo - San Pietro in Vincoli - Rome).jpg|thumb|left|140px|right|Mistranslation: [[Michelangelo]]'s horned [[Moses]]]] Efforts to translate the Bible into English had their [[martyr]]s. [[William Tyndale]] (c. 1494–1536) was convicted of [[heresy]] at [[Antwerp]], was strangled to death while tied at the stake, and then his dead body was burned.<ref>{{Citation |last=Farris |first=Michael |title=From Tyndale to Madison |year=2007 |page=37}}.</ref> Earlier, [[John Wycliffe]] (c. mid-1320s – 1384) had managed to die a natural death, but 30 years later the [[Council of Constance]] in 1415 declared him a heretic and decreed that his works and earthly remains should be burned; the order, confirmed by [[Pope Martin V]], was carried out in 1428, and Wycliffe's corpse was exhumed and burned and the ashes cast into the [[River Swift]]. Debate and religious [[schism]] over different translations of religious texts continue, as demonstrated by, for example, the [[King James Only movement]].
A famous ''mistranslation'' of a [[Biblical]] text is the rendering of the [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] word {{lang|he|קֶרֶן|rtl=yes}} (''keren''), which has several meanings, as "horn" in a context where it more plausibly means "beam of light": as a result, for centuries artists, including sculptor [[Michelangelo]], have rendered [[Moses|Moses the Lawgiver]] with horns growing from his forehead. [[File:Chinese quran.jpg|thumb|100px|[[Chinese language|Chinese]] translation, verses 33–34 of ''Quran'''s [[Ya Sin|''surah'' (chapter) 36]]]] Such fallibility of the translation process has contributed to the [[Islamic]] world's ambivalence about translating the ''[[Quran]]'' (also spelled ''Koran'') from the original [[Arabic]], as received by the prophet [[Muhammad]] from [[Allah]] (God) through the angel [[Gabriel]] incrementally between 609 and 632 C.E., the year of Muhammad's death. During prayers, the ''Quran'', as the miraculous and inimitable word of Allah, is recited only in Arabic. However, as of 1936, it had been translated into at least 102 languages.<ref name = fatani>{{cite encyclopedia |first =Afnan|last = Fatani|title =Translation and the Qur'an|editor-link =Oliver Leaman|editor-first = Oliver| editor-last = Leaman|encyclopedia=The Qur'an: An Encyclopaedia|publisher = Routledge|date = 2006|pages = 657–669|isbn = 978-0415775298}}</ref>
A fundamental difficulty in translating the ''Quran'' accurately stems from the fact that an Arabic word, like a [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] or [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] word, may have a [[Polysemy|range of meanings]], depending on [[Context (language use)|context]]. This is said to be a linguistic feature, particularly of all [[Semitic languages]], that adds to the usual similar difficulties encountered in translating between any two languages.<ref name = fatani/> There is always an element of human judgment—of interpretation—involved in understanding and translating a text. Muslims regard any translation of the ''Quran'' as but one possible interpretation of the [[Classical Arabic|Quranic (Classical) Arabic]] text, and not as a full equivalent of that divinely communicated original. Hence such a translation is often called an "interpretation" rather than a translation.<ref>[[Malise Ruthven]], ''Islam in the World'', Granta, 2006, p. 90, {{ISBN|978-1-86207-906-9}}.</ref>
To complicate matters further, as with other languages, the meanings and usages of some expressions have changed ''over time'', between the Classical Arabic of the ''Quran'', and modern Arabic. Thus a modern Arabic speaker may misinterpret the meaning of a word or passage in the ''Quran''. Moreover, the interpretation of a Quranic passage will also depend on the historic context of Muhammad's life and of his early community. Properly researching that context requires a detailed knowledge of ''[[hadith]]'' and ''[[Prophetic biography|sirah]]'', which are themselves vast and complex texts. Hence, analogously to the translating of [[Translation#Chinese literature|Chinese literature]], an attempt at an accurate translation of the ''Quran'' requires a knowledge not only of the Arabic language and of the [[Target language (translation)|target language]], including their respective evolutions, but also a deep understanding of the two [[culture]]s involved.
== Technical translation == {{main|Technical translation}} [[Technical translation]] renders documents such as manuals, instruction sheets, internal memos, minutes, financial reports, and other documents for a limited audience (who are directly affected by the document) and whose useful life is often limited. Thus, a user guide for a particular model of refrigerator is useful only for the owner of the refrigerator, and will remain useful only as long as that refrigerator model is in use. Similarly, software documentation generally pertains to a particular software, whose applications are used only by a certain class of users.<ref>{{cite book|last=Byrne |first=Jody|year=2006 |title=Technical Translation: Usability Strategies for Translating Technical Documentation |publisher=Springer |location=Dordrecht}}</ref>

{{Unreferenced|date=August 2010}} __NOTOC__ '''The UK Dispersion Modelling Bureau''' is part of the [[Met Office]] (originally an abbreviation for Meteorological Office, but now the official name in itself) which is the [[United Kingdom|UK]]'s national weather and meteorological service. The meteorologists in the bureau are among the UK's leading experts in areas such:
* [[meteorology]] * [[air quality]] studies and forecasting * [[atmospheric dispersion modelling|air pollution dispersion modelling]] * [[Flue gas|industrial emissions]]
==Consultancy services== The bureau has a team of air quality specialists dedicated to providing advice, support, and consultancy service to industry, government, local authorities and private consultants. The team has particular expertise with long and short range [[atmospheric pollution dispersion modelling]] using the [[NAME (dispersion model)|NAME]], [[AERMOD]], [[ADMS 3|ADMS]], BOXURB and other dispersion models.
The bureau's consultancy services include:
* height assessments of industrial stacks discharging airborne [[pollutants]] * long-term environmental impact studies of airborne pollutant emissions * scenario modelling and analyses of [[accidental release source terms|accidental releases]] of airborne pollutants * air pollution forecasting studies * studies of long-range trans-boundary transport of air pollutants * urban air quality modelling * providing site-specific meteorological data
==See also==
*[[Accidental release source terms]] *[[Bibliography of atmospheric dispersion modeling|Bibliography of atmospheric dispersion modelling]] *[[Air pollution dispersion terminology]] *[[Air Quality Modeling Group]] *[[Air Resources Laboratory]] *[[AP 42 Compilation of Air Pollutant Emission Factors]] *[[Atmospheric dispersion modeling|Atmospheric dispersion modelling]] *[[Atmospheric Studies Group]] *[[List of atmospheric dispersion models]] *[[UK Atmospheric Dispersion Modelling Liaison Committee]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book | author=Turner, D.B. | title=Workbook of atmospheric dispersion estimates: an introduction to dispersion modeling| edition=2nd| publisher=CRC Press | year=1994 | isbn=1-56670-023-X }} [https://web.archive.org/web/20071105075907/http://www.crcpress.com/shopping_cart/products/product_detail.asp?sku=L1023&parent_id=&pc= www.crcpress.com] *{{cite book | author=Beychok, M.R. | title=[[Fundamentals Of Stack Gas Dispersion]]| edition=4th| publisher=self-published | year=2005 | isbn=0-9644588-0-2}} [http://www.air-dispersion.com www.air-dispersion.com]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060113231208/http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/environment/serv4.html UK Dispersion Modelling Bureau web site] * [http://admlc.wordpress.com UK Atmospheric Dispersion Modelling Liaison Committee (ADMLC) web site] * [http://www.arl.noaa.gov/ Air Resources Laboratory (ARL)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060925023209/http://www.epa.gov/oar/oaqps/organization/aqad/aqmg.html Air Quality Modeling Group] * [http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/ Met Office web site] * [http://www.air-dispersion.com/feature.html Error propagation in air dispersion modelling]

會保存遺産喃 | image = Vietnamese Nôm Preservation Foundation logo.gif | image_size = | alt = | caption = | abbreviation = VNPF | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date|1999|||df=y}} | founder = | type = [[NGO]] | tax_id = | registration_id = | status = active | purpose = [[Language preservation]] | headquarters = [[Cary, North Carolina]] | location = 229 Beachers Brook Lane, Cary, North Carolina 27511, United States | coords = | fields = [[Linguistics]] | language = English, [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] | owner = | sec_gen = | leader_title = President | leader_name = Prof. [[John Balaban]] | board_of_directors = | staff = | volunteers = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{url|nomfoundation.org}} {{en icon}}
{{url|nomfoundation.org/vn}} {{vi icon}} }} {{Infobox Chinese |title = Vietnamese Nôm Preservation Foundation |collapse = yes |t = 喃字遺產保護會 |s = 喃字遗产保护会 |p = Nánzì Yíchǎn Bǎohù Huì |bpmf = ㄋㄢˊ ㄗˋ ㄧˊ ㄔㄢˇ ㄅㄠˇ ㄏㄨˋ ㄏㄨㄟˋ |qn = Hội Bảo Tồn Di Sản Chữ Nôm |hn = 會保存遺産喃 or
會保存遺産𡨸喃 }} {{Contains Vietnamese text}} The '''Vietnamese Nôm Preservation Foundation''' ({{lang-vi|Hội Bảo Tồn Di Sản Chữ Nôm}}; [[Hán Nôm]]: {{vi-nom|會保存遺産喃}}), shortened as the '''Nôm Foundation'''{{cite web|title=Vietnamese Nôm Preservation Foundation|work=[[Library of Congress]] Name Authority File|url=http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/nr2002015127.html|accessdate=August 5, 2014}} and abbreviated as '''VNPF''', is an American nonprofit agency for [[language preservation]] headquartered in [[Cary, North Carolina]], with an office in [[Hanoi]], [[Vietnam]].{{cite web|title=Contact|work=Vietnamese Nôm Preservation Foundation|url=http://nomfoundation.org/Contact|accessdate=August 8, 2014}} Established in 1999, it has been engaging in the preservation of [[Chữ Nôm]] script (an ancient, [[logographic]], [[Chinese character]]-based script once used by the [[Vietnamese people]] to write their language) remained in manuscripts, [[inscription]]s and [[woodcut|woodblock]]s.{{cite web|title=About the VNPF|work=Vietnamese Nôm Preservation Foundation|url=http://nomfoundation.org/|accessdate=August 4, 2014}}{{cite web|last=Balaban|first=John|title=Update on Nom|work=Language Log, Linguistic Data Consortium, the [[University of Pennsylvania]]|url=http://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/nll/?p=5212|date=July 16, 2013|accessdate=August 4, 2014}} ==Foundation== The preservation of Chữ Nôm practiced by the Foundation involves different approaches, such as the electronic font carving, ideograms entered into [[Unicode]] and the International Standard (regulated by [[ISO]]), [[digitization]] for displaying Nôm on the [[Internet]] and the revival of ancient works in [[literature]], history, culture, [[music]]s and the [[arts]] (e.g. the [[chamber music]] called [[Ca trù]]).{{r|niu}} With the help of voluntary [[linguist]]s, [[lexicographer]]s and computer professionals from many part of the world, the VNPF publishes Nôm dictionary in both print edition and digital format, making it the first Nôm dictionary in [[TrueType]].{{r|vnpf1}}{{cite web|last=Balaban|first=John|title=The Hán-Nôm Special Collection Digitization Project|work=Southeast Asia Digital Library, [[Northern Illinois University]]|url=http://sea.lib.niu.edu/project/about_hannom|accessdate=August 4, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812213937/http://sea.lib.niu.edu/project/about_hannom|archive-date=August 12, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} While granting scholarships to American and Vietnamese students who intend to research this subject,{{r|vnpf1}} the VNPF also sponsored two international Nôm conferences and represented Nôm script at the international meetings held by the [[Ideographic Rapporteur Group]].{{r|niu}}{{r|lse}} ==Projects== There has been a scheme called ''the Digitization Project of the Hán-Nôm Special Collection'' cooperatively implemented by the Vietnamese Nôm Preservation Foundation and the [[National Library of Vietnam]]. In 2006, a Memorandum was signed by the VNPF, enabling it to build a digital library based on the existing collections in the National Library which stores world's most ancient scripts written in Hán Nôm.{{r|niu}} Through the resources from the National Library, the VNPF had digitized more than 2000 Hán Nôm texts till 2013.{{r|upenn}} Meanwhile, the VNPF has been directing another project to digitize the [[Thắng Nghiêm Temple]] ({{lang-vi|Chùa Thắng Nghiêm|links=no}}; Hán Nôm: {{vi-nom|寺勝嚴}}) near [[Hanoi]]. Constructed in the early 11th century under an imperial order, it is an important historical site for the Asian [[Buddhism]]. The project will be completed by 2014, bringing a web database of the full record from the Temple, including manuscripts, epigraphical materials and visual heritages in Chữ Nôm. Additionally, the building structure and [[iconographical]] ideas of the Thắng Nghiêm Temple will be shown in a photographic overview.{{cite web|last=Schmid|first=D. Neil|title=Digitizing a Vietnamese Buddhist Temple: The Vietnamese Nôm Preservation Foundation's Thắng Nghiêm Temple Project|publisher=[[Academia.edu]]|work=Centre for the Study of Religion and Culture in Asia, the [[University of Groningen]]|url=https://www.academia.edu/5465460/Digitizing_a_Vietnamese_Buddhist_Temple|accessdate=August 5, 2014}} Receiving funds from private donators, the Chino Cienega Foundation in [[California]], the International Music and Arts Foundation in [[Liechtenstein]], [[North Carolina State University]] and the [[U.S. Embassy in Hanoi]], this project is aimed at recording Vietnamese Buddhism, offering historical documents of the Temple, opening a path for further temple digitization in the future and letting the materials to be globally accessible.{{r|ug}} [[File:VNPF Board 2013.jpg|thumb|320px|Board of the Vietnamese Nôm Preservation Foundation at 2013 meeting in [[Palm Springs]], together with a scholar recipient John Phan]] ==Staff== Since 1999, Professor [[John Balaban]] at [[North Carolina State University]] has been the president of the VNPF. In 2000, he published his influential book ''Spring Essence: The Poetry of Ho Xuan Huong'' (written in both [[chữ quốc ngữ]] and Hán Nôm), which was the first Nôm book ever printed in the modern times.{{cite web|title=Preservation of the Vietnamese Nôm Script|work=Asia Research Centre, the [[London School of Economics and Political Science]], the [[University of London]]|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/asiaResearchCentre/events/individual/2012/121116-Balaban.aspx|accessdate=August 4, 2014}} Dr. Ngô Thanh Nhàn, a Vietnamese characters researcher at [[Temple University]] and a [[computational linguist]] at [[New York University]], was the vice president from 1999 to 2007.{{cite web|title=Contact|work=the Center for Vietnamese Philosophy, Culture & Society, College of Liberal Arts, [[Temple University]]|url=http://www.temple.edu/vietnamese_center/nomstudies/contacts.html|accessdate=August 4, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819082509/http://www.temple.edu/vietnamese_center/nomstudies/contacts.html|archive-date=August 19, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|title=Ngô Thanh Nhàn|work=Computer Science Department, [[New York University]]|url=http://www.cs.nyu.edu/~nhan/home.html|accessdate=August 5, 2014}} Currently the VNPF has two vice presidents (Ngô Trung Viet{{cite web|author=Oronte|title=What Ngo Trung Viet Knows|work=[[Inside Higher Ed]]|url=http://www.insidehighered.com/blogs/the_education_of_oronte_churm/what_ngo_trung_viet_knows|date=July 20, 2007|accessdate=August 5, 2014}} and Brad Crittenden{{cite web|title=The people|work=Vietnamese Nôm Preservation Foundation|url=http://nomfoundation.org/About-the-Foundation/The-people|accessdate=August 5, 2014}}) and one secretary/treasurer (Stephen O. Lesser).{{r|vnpf2}} ==See also== * The [[Institute of Hán-Nôm Studies]], a similar research center in Hanoi, Vietnam. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== ===Tools provided by the VNPF=== *{{cite web|title=Nôm Lookup Tool|url=http://nomfoundation.org/nom-tools/Nom-Lookup-Tool|publisher=the Vietnamese Nôm Preservation Foundation|accessdate=August 8, 2014}} *{{cite web|title=Nôm Dictionary|url=http://nomfoundation.org/nom-tools/Nom-Dictionary|publisher=the Vietnamese Nôm Preservation Foundation|accessdate=August 8, 2014}} ===Research production=== *{{cite web|title=The Han-Nom Special Collection Digitization Project: Digitized selected manuscripts from the Vietnamese Nom Preservation Foundation|url=http://sea.lib.niu.edu/fedora/repository/SEAImages:NLVNPFManuscripts/-/The%20Han-Nom%20Special%20Collection|publisher=Southeast Asia Digital Library, [[Northern Illinois University]]|accessdate=August 4, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813072005/http://sea.lib.niu.edu/fedora/repository/SEAImages%3ANLVNPFManuscripts/-/The%20Han-Nom%20Special%20Collection|archive-date=August 13, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vietnamese Nom Preservation Foundation}} [[Category:Research institutes in the United States]] [[Category:Research institutes in Vietnam]] [[Category:Research institutes established in 1999]] [[Category:Linguistic research institutes]] [[Category:Organizations based in North Carolina]]

{{Infobox sportsperson | headercolor = | name = Zvi Nishri (Orloff) | image = | image_size = <!--Only for images narrower than 220 pixels.--> | caption = | birth_name = | fullname = | nickname = | nationality = Russian-born Palestinian/Israeli | residence = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1878|1|4}} | birth_place = Russia | death_date = {{Death date and age|1973|7|22|1878|1|4}} | death_place = | height = <!-- {{convert|}} (yyyy) --> | weight = <!-- {{convert|}} (yyyy) --> | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | country = | sport = | event = | collegeteam = | club = | team = | turnedpro = | coach = | retired = | coaching = | worlds = | regionals = | nationals = | olympics = | paralympics = | highestranking = | pb = | medaltemplates = | show-medals = }} '''Zvi Nishri ''' (January 4, 1878 – July 22, 1973) was a pioneer in modern [[physical education]] in [[Mandatory Palestine|British Mandate for Palestine]] and later, [[Israel]].<ref name="google1">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qpiphgls99IC&pg=PA145&dq=%22Zvi+Nishri%22&hl=en&ei=whWyTpqVD-LW0QGs4qTGAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Zvi%20Nishri%22&f=false |title=The International Jewish Sports Hall of Fame |page=145 |author=Joseph M. Siegman |publisher= |date=1992 |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref><ref name="google2">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9W1YAAAAYAAJ&q=%22Zvi+Nishri%22&dq=%22Zvi+Nishri%22&hl=en&ei=whWyTpqVD-LW0QGs4qTGAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAQ |title=Physical education and sport in the Jewish history and culture: proceedings of the second international seminar, July 1977 |author=Mekhon Ṿingaiṭ le-ḥinukh gufani |publisher= |date=1977 |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boeliem.com/content/2007/764.html |title=Physical Education and Sport in Israel |publisher=Boeliem.com |date=April 12, 2008 |author=Haim Kaufman |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kadisha.biz/ShowItem.aspx?levelId=59689&template=18&ID=5787 |title=חברה קדישא תל אביב יפו והמחוז |publisher=Kadisha.biz |date= |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref><ref name="autogeneratedil">{{cite web|url=http://www.tau.ac.il/tarbut/tezot/bloom/EtanBloom-PhD-ArthurRuppin.pdf |title=Arthur Ruppin and the Production of the Modern Hebrew Culture|author= Etan Bloom |publisher= |date=December 1, 2008 |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
==Biography== Zvi Orloff (later Nishri) was born to a [[Jewish]] family in Russia, where he served as a soldier.<ref name="google1"/><ref name="google3">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AgmDAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Zvi+Nishri%22&dq=%22Zvi+Nishri%22&hl=en&ei=whWyTpqVD-LW0QGs4qTGAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAw |title=Encyclopedia of Jews in Sports |author1=Bernard Postal |author2=Jesse Silver |author3=Roy Silver |publisher=Bloch Pub. Co. |date=1965 |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref> His sister was the sculptor, [[Chana Orloff]]. [[Raful Eitan]] was a nephew.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Iav7igW5CQC&pg=PA18&dq=nishri+ukraine&hl=en&ei=eyOyTpyHGLOq0AGhw7D9CQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=nishri%20ukraine&f=false |title=A Soldier's Story: The Life and Times of an Israeli War Hero |author=Raful Eitan |publisher= SP Books|ISBN=1-56171-094-6|date= 1992|accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
He [[aliyah|immigrated]] to Palestine in 1903.<ref name="google1"/> He initially worked as a laborer, in [[Petah Tikva]].<ref name="google1"/>
==Physical education career== In 1906 he became involved in physical education.<ref name="google1"/><ref name="google4">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RcZtAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Zvi+Nishri%22&dq=%22Zvi+Nishri%22&hl=en&ei=whWyTpqVD-LW0QGs4qTGAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAg |title=Encyclopedia of Zionism and Israel |author=Raphael Patai |publisher=Herzl Press |date=1971 |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref> In 1908, he started to teach physical education, and by 1912, he was involved in training teachers on the subject.<ref name="google1"/><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Iav7igW5CQC&pg=PA18&dq=%22tZvi+Nishri%22&hl=en&ei=ARyyTsKtNMH00gHO0vTQAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22tZvi%20Nishri%22&f=false |title=A Soldier's Story: The Life and ... |author=Raful Eitan |publisher= |date= |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref> In 1911, he introduced [[Scandinavia]]n gymnastics to Palestine.<ref name="google4"/> He taught at the [[Herzliya Hebrew Gymnasium|Herzliya High School]] for 40 years.<ref name="google4"/>
Nishri authored the first physical education publications in Hebrew, and established the first physical education and sports terminology in Hebrew.<ref name="google1"/><ref name="google4"/> In 1913, he began a prolific career as an author, writing publications on gymnastics, football, and other physical education topics.<ref name="google1"/><ref name="autogeneratedil"/><ref name="google4"/><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=khHwAAAAMAAJ&q=%22tZvi+Nishri%22&dq=%22tZvi+Nishri%22&hl=en&ei=ARyyTsKtNMH00gHO0vTQAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA |title=Comparative physical education and sport: proceedings of an international seminar|author1=Uriel Simri |author2=Mekhon Ṿingaiṭ le-ḥinukh gufani |author3=Israel. Rashut ha-sporṭ ṿeha-ḥinukh-ha-gufani |publisher= Wingate Institute for Physical Education and Sport|date=1979|accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
Nishri was a founder in Palestine of the [[List of Maccabi sports clubs and organizations|Maccabi]] movement, which he coached in gymnastics, and of the [[Hebrew Scouts Movement in Israel|Hebrew Scout Movement]].<ref name="google1"/><ref name="google3"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EzogAQAAMAAJ&q=%22Zvi+Nishri%22&dq=%22Zvi+Nishri%22&hl=en&ei=whWyTpqVD-LW0QGs4qTGAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEsQ6AEwBg |title=Israel magazine |publisher=Spotlight Publication Ltd. |date= 1969 |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maccabiusa.com/1900s.html |title=History: The 1900s |publisher=Maccabiusa.com |date= |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
==Awards and recognition== Nishri was inducted as a member of the [[International Jewish Sports Hall of Fame]] in 1981.<ref name="google1"/> The [[Wingate Institute]] established a prize in his honor.<ref name="google2"/> In addition, the Wingate Institute's Terner Pedagogical Centre contains the Zvi Nishri Archives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wingate.org.il/Index.asp?CategoryID=479&ArticleID=662 |title=מכון וינגייט – חיים של איכות Wingate – Units at |publisher=Wingate |date= |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
